text: Hi everyone, I am Pietro Boselli, Dr. Pietro Boselli actually.

text: Today we're going to talk about Fermat's last theorem.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: He had a hobby, a passion for math, so he would go back home and write his theorems and conjectures.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Fermat's notebook had lots of conjectures.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: He would write down saying, oh, I have an awesome proof of this, but I have no time to write it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Over the centuries, mathematicians went through this book and found proof to all his conjectures, apart from the last theorem.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The last theorem was very interesting.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Many people attempted the solution and thought they found it, but then somebody proved them wrong.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Andrew Wiles discovered this theorem when he was 10 years old and became obsessed with it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: He worked in secret because so many people attempted and failed.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: He found a solution and he presented it to the public and he was acclaimed worldwide.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The Queen knighted him and it was a great success until somebody actually found an error in his proof.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: He was not gonna give up that easily and he worked for another year, full time, and he found the solution.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If you have x to the n plus y to the n is equal to z to the n. If n is a positive integer greater than 2, this equation is never true.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It looks very simple, but in mathematics, proving that something doesn't exist is always harder than proving that something exists.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is a variety of applications in cryptography, writing encryptions and codes.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and all of that secret stuff.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And it opened up a whole new world for mathematics, a whole new branch of mathematics.
